item.title: Juno Spacecraft Reveals Spectacular Cyclones At Jupiter's Poles
item.description: May 25, 2017 - The NASA has spotted enormous cyclones at the gas giant's north and south poles. The probe has also returned other data that have project scientists scratching their heads.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 25, 2017 - The NASA has spotted enormous cyclones at the gas giant's north and south poles. The probe has also returned other data that have project scientists scratching their heads. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/25/530002348/juno-spacecraft-reveals-spectacular-cyclones-at-jupiters-poles

item.title: Many Adults Don't Think Exposure To Vaping Is Bad For Kids
item.description: May 25, 2017 - Nicotine, heavy metals and tiny particles that can harm the lungs float around in the aerosol from e-cigarettes. But a survey finds many adults don't think secondhand vape is dangerous for children.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 25, 2017 - Nicotine, heavy metals and tiny particles that can harm the lungs float around in the aerosol from e-cigarettes. But a survey finds many adults don't think secondhand vape is dangerous for children. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/25/530026958/many-adults-dont-think-exposure-to-vaping-is-bad-for-kids

item.title: How Elections Influence Judges
item.description:
May 25, 2017 - Social science research looks at the relationship between how judges rule and how they are influenced by election campaigns.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/05/25/529977252/how-elections-influence-judges
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 25, 2017 - Social science research looks at the relationship between how judges rule and how they are influenced by election campaigns. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/25/529977252/how-elections-influence-judges

item.title: Eating Chocolate, A Little Each Week, May Lower The Risk Of A Heart Flutter
item.description: May 24, 2017 - The latest evidence that a chocolate habit may lower your risk of heart disease: A study finds people who ate small amounts of chocolate several times a week had a lower risk of atrial fibrillation.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 24, 2017 - The latest evidence that a chocolate habit may lower your risk of heart disease: A study finds people who ate small amounts of chocolate several times a week had a lower risk of atrial fibrillation. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/05/24/529843647/eating-chocolate-a-little-each-week-may-lower-the-risk-of-a-heart-flutter

item.title: Fitness Trackers: Good at Measuring Heart Rate, Not So Good At Measuring Calories
item.description: May 24, 2017 - A study of seven popular fitness trackers found they are generally good at measuring heart rate, but may mislead consumers about how many calories they have burned.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 24, 2017 - A study of seven popular fitness trackers found they are generally good at measuring heart rate, but may mislead consumers about how many calories they have burned. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/24/529839681/fitness-trackers-good-at-measuring-heart-rate-not-so-good-at-measuring-calories

item.title: Miami's Zika Outbreak Began Months Before It Was First Detected
item.description: May 24, 2017 - Travelers infected with the Zika virus in the Caribbean brought it to South Florida multiple times before officials realized it had reached the U.S., an analysis of virus genomes finds.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 24, 2017 - Travelers infected with the Zika virus in the Caribbean brought it to South Florida multiple times before officials realized it had reached the U.S., an analysis of virus genomes finds. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/24/529721114/miamis-zika-outbreak-began-months-before-it-was-first-detected

item.title: Doctors Once Thought Bananas Cured Celiac Disease. They Saved Kids' Lives — At A Cost
item.description: May 24, 2017 - In the early 20th century, kids with the disease faced severe malnutrition, even death. The banana-based diet doctors came up with seemed to cure them — but led kids back to foods that made them sick.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 24, 2017 - In the early 20th century, kids with the disease faced severe malnutrition, even death. The banana-based diet doctors came up with seemed to cure them — but led kids back to foods that made them sick. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/05/24/529527564/doctors-once-thought-bananas-cured-celiac-disease-it-saved-kids-lives-at-a-cost

item.title: How The Biggest Animal On Earth Got So Big
item.description: May 23, 2017 - Whales might be the largest animals on the planet, but they haven't always been so huge. Researchers say the ocean giants only became enormous fairly recently, and over a short period of time.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 23, 2017 - Whales might be the largest animals on the planet, but they haven't always been so huge. Researchers say the ocean giants only became enormous fairly recently, and over a short period of time. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/23/529505847/how-the-biggest-animal-on-earth-got-so-big

item.title: 3.3 Million-Year-Old Fossil Sheds Light On How The Spine Evolved
item.description: May 23, 2017 - It's hard evidence that the type of spinal segmentation and numbering found in modern humans emerged 3.3 million years ago, the scientists say. The remarkable fossil was discovered in Ethiopia.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 23, 2017 - It's hard evidence that the type of spinal segmentation and numbering found in modern humans emerged 3.3 million years ago, the scientists say. The remarkable fossil was discovered in Ethiopia. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/23/529693497/3-3-million-year-old-fossil-sheds-light-on-how-the-spine-evolved

item.title: Me, Myself, and IKEA: What Our Love For Swedish Furniture Says About Narcissism
item.description: May 22, 2017 - In general, people show a subtle bias toward the self. This is why we love the IKEA furniture we've built, and gravitate toward others with the same name. But there are much larger implications, too.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 22, 2017 - In general, people show a subtle bias toward the self. This is why we love the IKEA furniture we've built, and gravitate toward others with the same name. But there are much larger implications, too. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/22/529128529/me-myself-and-ikea-what-our-love-for-swedish-furniture-says-about-narcissism

item.title: International Eel Smuggling Scheme Centers On Maine
item.description: May 22, 2017 - NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Bill Trotter, a fishery and environmental reporter for the Bangor Daily News, about the illegal eel fishing scheme in Maine.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 22, 2017 - NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Bill Trotter, a fishery and environmental reporter for the Bangor Daily News, about the illegal eel fishing scheme in Maine. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/22/529550226/international-eel-smuggling-scheme-centers-on-maine

item.title: At 94, Lithium-Ion Pioneer Eyes A New Longer-Lasting Battery
item.description: May 22, 2017 - In 1980, John Goodenough's work led to the lithium-ion battery, now found in everything from phones to electric cars. He and fellow researchers say they've come up with a faster-charging alternative.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 22, 2017 - In 1980, John Goodenough's work led to the lithium-ion battery, now found in everything from phones to electric cars. He and fellow researchers say they've come up with a faster-charging alternative. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/05/22/529116034/at-94-lithium-ion-pioneer-eyes-a-new-longer-lasting-battery

item.title: Pediatricians Advise No Fruit Juice Until Kids Are 1
item.description: May 22, 2017 - Older kids should limit the amount of juice they drink too. Whole fruit is better than juice because it contains fiber, which slows the absorption of sugar and fills you up the way juice doesn't.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 22, 2017 - Older kids should limit the amount of juice they drink too. Whole fruit is better than juice because it contains fiber, which slows the absorption of sugar and fills you up the way juice doesn't. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/22/528970924/pediatricians-advise-no-fruit-juice-until-kids-are-1

item.title: Cloud Eggs: The Latest Instagram Food Fad Is Actually Centuries Old
item.description: May 21, 2017 - The fanciful dish was meant to impress nearly 400 years ago, so don't roll your eyes at photos of these pretty edibles: They're actually a time-honored tradition tinged with a bit of kitchen science.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 21, 2017 - The fanciful dish was meant to impress nearly 400 years ago, so don't roll your eyes at photos of these pretty edibles: They're actually a time-honored tradition tinged with a bit of kitchen science. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/05/21/529127751/cloud-eggs-the-latest-instagram-food-fad-is-actually-centuries-old

item.title: Why Brain Scientists Are Still Obsessed With The Curious Case Of Phineas Gage
item.description: May 21, 2017 - In 1848, a railroad worker survived an accident that drove a 13-pound iron bar through his head. The injury changed his personality, and our understanding of the brain.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 21, 2017 - In 1848, a railroad worker survived an accident that drove a 13-pound iron bar through his head. The injury changed his personality, and our understanding of the brain. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/21/528966102/why-brain-scientists-are-still-obsessed-with-the-curious-case-of-phineas-gage
